data.author: BritishPeculeum
data.content: Disco, the most recent RNS’s discussing the CLN activity are a good place to look to see what the running balance of shares are.  The RNS on 23rd January 2026 states the most up-to-date sum of outstanding shares in the Company at a figure of 287,995,114. “Further to the announcement on 4 December 2025, the Company confirms that the CLN holder, Indigo, has converted $536,000 at 1.483 pence per share into 26,981,814 new ordinary shares of no par value in the Company ("New Ordinary Shares"). Application has been made for the New Ordinary Shares to be admitted to trading on AIM ("Admission"). It is expected that Admission will become effective and dealings will commence at 8:00 am on or around 26 January 2026. The Company has been informed that Indigo has entered into agreements to divest 24,181,814 of the New Ordinary Shares to various equity funds and family offices in Europe and elsewhere, as soon as practicable following Admission. Following Admission, the Company will have 287,995,114 ordinary shares outstanding. Shareholders may use this number as the denominator for the calculation by which they will determine if they are required to notify their interest in, or a change in their interest in, the issued share capital of the Company.”

data.author: BritishPeculeum
data.content: Oh Dear Alan there is definitely a case to be argued of incompetence from the BOD’s to not foresee this latest blunder.  But I think that the Board actually know what they are doing. The thought did cross my mind that why would professional investors, family offices etc deal in shares for PXC from Indigo, if the sp in the market drops sufficiently to leave Indigo with little or no margin to profit from it?  If they wanted to invest in PXC, why wouldn’t they just pick up shares from the market instead? Could be a smart thing the BOD’s are doing to push the sp down, as a hedge against Indigo dropping a load of  cheap shares onto the market.  If the BOD’s keep dropping bad news to keep the sp depressed, it at least keeps the supply of shares in circulation relatively low.  This strategy only works in the case that the new mystery investor gets his finger out and the BOD’s secure the new funding in fairly short order, and some of the bond funds are used to redeem the Indigo CLN’s early. Short term pain; long term gain.  I’m ok with that, because I’m so underwater, I’m going nowhere fast in any case.  If my theory is correct then we could be thanking the BOD’s for such incompetence.  Keep the sp as low as possible until “James” gets his feet under the table… that’s James, with the Bond, by the way. GLA.

data.author: grasshopperblue
data.content: I looked it up and this is the answer i got.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          what is a prepayment of a convertible loan note Prepayment of a convertible loan note (CLN) is the act of a borrower repaying the principal and accrued interest of the debt before its scheduled maturity date or before it converts into equity. In the context of early-stage startup financing, prepayment is a highly sensitive and often restricted term for the following reasons: 1. Investor Resistance Loss of Upside: Investors generally oppose prepayment clauses because they want the option to convert their debt into high-value equity. If a company prepays the loan just before a major funding round or exit, the investor loses the "upside" of converting at a discount or under a valuation cap. "No Prepayment" Clauses: Most standard startup term sheets explicitly state that the company cannot prepay the notes without the prior written consent of the noteholders. 2. Strategic Use for Founders Avoiding Dilution: Founders may seek the right to prepay if the company becomes unexpectedly profitable or has access to cheaper capital. By repaying the loan in cash, they avoid the "unfavorable terms" of conversion that would dilute their ownership. Clean-Up: Prepayment can be used to "clean up" a cap table by removing small debt holders before a new institutional investor comes on board. 3. Automatic Repayment Events Prepayment can sometimes be triggered automatically by specific "Events of Default" or corporate changes, rather than a voluntary choice by the company: Insolvency: Legal requirements may force repayment if the company enters bankruptcy. Change of Control: If the company is acquired, notes may be paid off immediately in cash rather than converted, depending on the agreed terms. Material Breach: Failure to follow the agreed-upon negative covenants can trigger immediate repayment. 4. Valuation Implications In financial modeling, the "callability" (the issuer's right to prepay) reduces the fair value of the note for the investor. If a note is "called" for prepayment, the holder usually has a final window to choose between accepting the cash prepayment or exercising their conversion right to shares.

Global copper production was around 23 million metric tons (MT) in 2024, with Chile leading by far (5.3 MT, 23%) Never mind the electricity gap... But what about the copper gap? Planned hyper scale and global data centres alone will use circa 10-20% of global copper supply. What about everything else? EV - is the biggest rising demand , extending replacing ageing power grid networks, general construction wiring, military demand, developing world - ie virgin demand - in Africa, India and booming South East Asia It's like trying to squeeze the contents of the Hoover dam through a garden hose. We need to find and build another 5-8 Escondidas in the next 6 years. OR / AND price has to rise a lot.“ Trek

data.author: BritishPeculeum
data.content: MT… so a topic of conversation on this and other BB’s at the time that NIU bond deal went sour, was the question of whether PXC could use Bond capital to pay down the coupon.  In usual circumstances, where capital is raised as development capital (which in this case, it was) there will invariably be a clause in the contract prohibiting the use of the capital for P and L expenditure, which, by its definition, includes the servicing of the coupon.  The prohibition on coupon servicing will probably have been specific in the contract aswell.  Given where the NAV for Empire is, give NIU any opportunity to foreclose on it for the £5m it is in for, and it will take it, no question.  Any breach of duty, contract or performance under the terms of the NIU deal will automatically be terminal for PXC. The LOI was specifically a non-binding LOI, so no legal standing.  Plus I highly doubt that Indigo has anything to do with the Investor.  The situation is that in 2024, PXC entered into its original arrangement with Riverfort to provide working capital for PXC in a deal that was very favourable to PXC, but contingent on PXC securing at least $25m from a bond raise, for PXC to benefit from those favourable terms.  With the NIU deal in 2024, it appeared to everyone that PXC had pulled it off and delivered on the Riverfort condition, only then for NIU to pull out.  It left PXC in 2025 having to draw down additional funds on the Riverfort deal, but the cash costs and fees were just too punitive to continue with Riverfort on that basis whilst they waited for the bond deal to arrive, which of course it hasn’t. The Indigo deal at the end of 2025 was concluded because it was cheaper to service month to month, which matters when you’re trying to survive to the next funding event, but it has come with a greater dilutive effect upon shareholders.  It was probably the right thing to do.  It’s possible that the Directors that are now suspended may have “taken one for the team” by doing what they have done, although at this stage it’s difficult to say with any certainty whether that is the situation. The most sensible solution for the Company right now will be to get into a room with Indigo, to establish how it can structure something around a settlement with Riverfort, and that will ensure that the Company does not default on the payment of the Coupon to NIU.  That is going to come at a cost to shareholders.  Sub-1p incoming I envisage. GLA GLA.

data.author: BritishPeculeum
data.content: MTSparky Three fundamentals here to unpack… First is the position of Indigo Capital.  Did the Company make misrepresentations to Indigo in securing funding in December 2025? If it did, Indigo could claim that it never would have made the funding in the first place had it known of the Company’s actual state of affairs.  Solid grounds for rescission? Probably Indigo’s strongest claim, which will also give them options in how they feature in where this goes from here. Second, is the position of Riverfort, and the early repayment of the Riverfort Debt.  The legality of that is challengable on all sorts of different levels.  On one of those, Riverfort has fought its way back into the picture, alongside Indigo, on a contractual point regarding prepayment.  Riverfort might have grounds to argue the opposite of Indigo, that it intended to exercise the CLN’s and would have done had PXC given prior notice of its intention to prepay.   I’m also not sure that the Company was in a position to repay Riverfort the whole sum due. Given the indebtedness of the Company,  given the Company’s known solvency position at the time that it repaid the sum, there’s a fair argument to say that a repayment in full to Riverfort was disproportionate and the repayment constituted a preference, when the Company was trading insolvently. Third, is the position of NIU.  NIU’s £5m debt is secured over the Empire assets.  Is PXC maintaining its coupon payments to NIU or is PXC in breach?  I can only assume (and hope) that the coupon payments are being properly maintained.  The moment that they are not, NIU will have the power to foreclose on the Empire assets, assuming that Konnex Resources Inc, is included in the schedule of ‘Group’ Companies on which NIU took security from PXC.  At this juncture, it appears that NIU is in the box seats IMO.  It has options at its disposal in the event of a default of PXC’s payment of the coupon.  It also has a potential claim regarding repayment to Riverfort being a ‘preference’, if it chooses not to/can’t foreclose. It’s game over for Riverfort, Indigo (and of course PXC) if NIU foreclose on Empire, so it is in the interests of Riverfort and Indigo to get into dialogue with PXC in how it can ensure that PXC stays alive.  It could be the golden ticket that PXC can use to buy itself a lifeline from either/both Riverfort/Indigo to get out of the mess PXC finds itself in. Fourth, any new institutional money coming in to salvage PXC is highly unlikely; PXC is a red flag unless or until the decks are cleared governance-wise and that’s not going to happen in the time that it will take before PXC’s cash runs dry. Fifth is the undisclosed investor.  If he is savvy enough and well-advised as I think, he would be doing exactly what he’s done: he’s got close enough to the action to find out what’s going on, and has held off long enough to allow all the excrement from the PXC barrel to float to the surface. Let’s  see how th

data.author: BritishPeculeum
data.content: Tbcx… Very valid points made by someone that actually recognises the truth of what’s really at stake at PXC right now.  Thank you. The point regarding running two CLN’s at the same time, I’m not sure I follow that argument.  Whilst it seems clear to me (brought about by the action of Riverfort potentially claiming prepayment fees from PXC for early redemption of Riverfort CLN’s) that Riverfort was not consulted, or even aware of, the early redemption of the Riverfort CLN’s, it does appear that PXC used the funds incoming from Indigo to prepay the Riverfort CLN’s, in which case, there would not have been two separate CLN’s (one from Riverfort and the other from Indigo) running in tandem at the same time. I do think, however, that the claim that NIU and/or Indigo might have against PXC for paying Riverfort as a preference in a situation where PXC was knowingly operating insolvently, has some legs.  Even if the case is weak, what it does do is block any additional sources of funding coming in to the business, and gives Indigo and NIU the whip hand at the negotiating table. GLA

data.author: BritishPeculeum
data.content: Latino, you are making a representation in your posts that PXC has secured $75m bond funding for the development of the Empire Mine. That is a complete misrepresentation of the position.  In Mid-2025, the Company entered into a NON-BINDING [emphasis added] letter of intent with a private individual investor, to invest in a bond arrangement.  Investors were told at an Investors’ Meeting in July 2025, that the undisclosed investor MAY [emphasis added] decide to pursue PXC funding, once it had resolved the sale of an existing stake in another investment elsewhere, BUT THAT HE WAS UNDER NO OBLIGATION TO PURSUE PXC AT ALL [emphasis added]. No further material change to that position has been made since July 2025. If you continue to misrepresent that the bond funding is secured with the undisclosed investor, I will report you. GLA
data.thread_title: RE: Cash runs out next few weeks, and CEO not worried??

data.author: tbcx
data.content: BritishPeculeum all valid stuff but somehow I don't think you'll be getting a coherent rebuttal to your points any time soon from folks who only heard about the company for the first time yesterday. It would be bad enough if there was just one CLN but that there were two effectively running concurrently, with both creditors apparently unaware of the extent of the others lending. We don't even know the true number of shares that have been issued because they already had form for late reporting and now any claim originating from CFO is under deep scrutiny. I don't know how anyone could unpick this to arrive at a valuation above zero. I am amazed the Nomad has allowed this to continue to trade. Even if this does miraculously stagger on to full year accounts deadline, can you imagine an auditor signing any of this off?

data.author: BritishPeculeum
data.content: Well said Forcella regarding these rampers, namely Latino and Magmanus_49.  Like vultures picking on the scraps.  Neither of them care about the complexities that PXC has to face ahead of it, just a quick buck in and out and they don’t care if they pump and dump and leave you holding the baby when this goes further down. Unlike Forcella, I’m really not convinced that Indigo will convert any more CLN’s now knowing that there are Governance, solvency and management issues at PXC.  Is it worth the risk of damaging its reputation with its clients any more than it already has done on PXC, by converting potentially up to another $500,000 worth of CLN’s at a VWAP of say 1p, for stock that could be worth $0 at some point in time in the near future, and most importantly, with no sign of development funding or cash runway beyond end Q2 on the table? Rightly so, there’ll be a serious amount of concern and no doubt, scrutiny at Indigo Capital over the validity of the representations made by PXC when this funding was put in place in December 2025. GLA

data.author: BritishPeculeum
data.content: 1nvest… It’s likely that Indigo Capital’s likelihood of getting its money out of this venture from here comes from establishing whether it was misrepresented by the Board up to the time that PXC sought funding from Indigo Capital, so that it can rescind the current funding, or renegotiate on better terms to Indigo.  It’s highly doubtful that converting more CLN’s at this stage makes any sense to them.  Converting a quarter of the value of its CLN’s on 23rd January 2026 at 1.48p, less than two weeks ago, and subsequently having sold those converted shares to Private Equity/family office clients at a margin on 1.48p has already blown up in their face, with PXC, within two weeks of those deals, announcing financial irregularities and a whole host of governance issues that will lead off the back of it.  Nah, that is very very unlikely. GLA
data.thread_title: RE: RNS - Vote of confidence from the CEO

data.author: BritishPeculeum
data.content: Magmanus_49… “The focus now shifts to execution: appointing a new CFO, securing short- and long-term financing, and stabilising operations. Importantly, these financing discussions were already referenced in the January 2025 update, when the share price was around 2–3p — a level that already appeared oversold at the time.” Some of what the new CFO will be challenged with early on in this process include: Indigo Capital will undoubtedly be looking closely at what and when certain things occurred in the time leading up to Indigo confirming funding to PXC, and asking questions as to whether any misrepresentation to Indigo occurred.  Did PXC know, or reasonably ought to have known of the misconduct, or any other disclosable matter before December 2025; and if so, would Indigo have invested at all if it had known of the misconduct prior to lending? Payment to Riverfort deemed as a ‘preference’.  There has to be a question from Indigo Capital, and on the same basis, NIU, regarding the context and timing of the raising of the funds by PXC from Indigo, and the repayment/prepayment of Riverfort with those funds raised from Indigo.  At the time of the payment to Riverfort, was PXC knowingly trading in cash flow insolvency? If Indigo and/or NIU can argue that PXC was technically insolvent at the time that it repaid Riverfort, either or both of them would have good grounds to argue that PXC has given preference to Riverfort in its payment to it as a creditor. These factors are material issues to PXC as BOD’s, and to any potential future funder/investors at this time.  Of course Indigo and NIU are going to be asking these questions of PXC at this time, looking for ways to secure their positions as best they can.  It would be naive of anyone investing in PXC not to consider this is the situation. The ramifications are that it: (a) slows any new funding down essentially to a halt, unless or until questions including misreps and preference questions have been satisfactorily answered to the positive; and (b) open the question that if Indigo were misrepresented by PXC, will Indigo rescind the current financing; and (c) opens the question that if Indigo and/or NIU can argue that PXC was technically insolvent at the time that it repaid/prepaid Riverfort whether that payment be recalled to PXC, as it was deemed to be paid in preference over other creditors? GLA DYOR

data.author: StanleyUK
data.content: Ousting Marcus and Richard should have happened a long time ago. They have served only to drain the company of cash in return for empty promises. While overdue, it’s good news that the remaining Board members are wrestling control of the company. There’s going to be a short period of having to unpick the mess we’ve been left in, and then shake the vultures off. No doubt this will come at a price, but it’s survivable. The company can then have a clean slate to progress the larger financing. It’s almost certain that previous finance discussions have fallen by the wayside because Wilkins and Edwards-Jones were perceived as untrustworthy sheisters. Ryan McDermott comes across as different, and anyone that’s met him at AGM’s would say the same. It’s just not been his company to run all these years despite being CEO because everything went through Wilkins. He’s now the proper frontman. They’ll be no more wild statements or speculation in RNS’s, which is why he likely didn’t mention the US investor today. It happens when it happens, and then we’ll be told. There’s still a viable company here, and while we’re likely to suffer dilution to clear the vultures out, I’d expect a far more sensible finance package to be put in place and the bonds finally kicked to the curb.

data.content: Ousting Marcus and Richard should have happened a long time ago. They have served only to drain the company of cash in return for empty promises. There’s still a viable company here, and while we’re likely to suffer dilution to clear the vultures out, I’d expect a far more sensible finance package to be put in place and the bonds finally kicked to the curb.

data.author: magmanus_49
data.content: Thanks — yes, I meant the CFO and Chairman. The removal of two senior executives should be viewed in context. Given the company’s underlying assets, it’s difficult to justify a market cap below £3m, yet that’s where the stock is currently trading. This disconnect highlights just how oversold the situation has become. The shares were already heavily de-rated from around 6p at the start of the year, so the additional ~50% drop following decisive board action feels excessive rather than fundamental. In reality, markets tend to reward strong governance and transparency, especially when issues are confronted rather than ignored. Existing shareholders — and new buyers — generally value that approach. It’s also worth noting that there are AIM shell companies with no meaningful assets trading at valuations above £3m. Against that backdrop, PXC’s valuation looks increasingly disconnected from reality. The focus now shifts to execution: appointing a new CFO, securing short- and long-term financing, and stabilising operations. Importantly, these financing discussions were already referenced in the January 2025 update, when the share price was around 2–3p — a level that already appeared oversold at the time. With hindsight, it’s reasonable to assume that the board changes announced recently had been in progress for some time, potentially explaining the prolonged weakness in the share price. With those issues now addressed, the stock finally has a chance to reset and re-rate from deeply depressed levels. In short, this looks less like a business impairment and more like capitulation pricing driven by uncertainty — uncertainty that is now being actively resolved.

My gold Sov is worth £800 ish, but should I choose to grind it into tiny fragments, placing each fragment in a lump of rock, and scatter those rocks over acres and bury it under tons more debris, I doubt you would give me a pound for the license to find it, despite 'certainty it is out there' especially if you had to jump through lengthy hoops to obtain permission and to gain the funds from others when more interested parties to extract the wealth can pull strings harder. I guess if the new skin is because the board feel certain or more confident funding is coming soon, then we will all be happy and singing from the same hymn sheet, juries out until then from me. Re posted as at the time, when I questioned the motive of the board buying more, I was just insulted so seems I was right, their skin in the game counts for nothing.  Likely the Americans will snap it up on the cheap after toying with the dim limey's, who in turn have used shareholders cash to ensure a good few years of lucrative salaries and perhaps more invisible earnings.

data.author: Mr0nions
data.content: Hey BritishPec , I did my research and many thanks. Enjoy: Strategic Report: Phoenix Copper (PXC.L) Liquidity Assessment The investment case for Phoenix Copper is now in a state of terminal duress following the suspension of its Executive Chairman and CFO on February 9, 2026. With the share price collapsing to 0.95p, the market is pricing in a high probability of insolvency or a dilutive restructuring that will effectively wipe out current equity holders. Break-Up Value & Assets The theoretical "Break-Up" value is based on the Empire Mine (8,434 acres in Idaho). The 2024 Pre-Feasibility Study (PFS) estimated a pre-tax Net Present Value (NPV) of $252 million, implying an asset-backed value of roughly 24p per share. However, in a distressed liquidation, this paper value serves as a ceiling for creditors, not a floor for shareholders. Secured lenders, led by Riverfort Global Opportunities, would likely seize the physical assets (land and equipment already staged in Idaho). For common shareholders, the recovery value in a fire sale is estimated at near-zero. Likelihood of Funding & Investors The probability of securing the proposed $75 million corporate bond has fallen to 15%. The ongoing "conduct investigation" makes the company un-investable for new institutional capital. The most likely source of survival capital is a "predatory" bridge loan from Riverfort or a distress-focused investor like NIU Invest (~45% probability). These investors typically utilize "death spiral" financing, converting debt into equity at massive discounts, which would further crush the share price. Rating: SELL / DURESS The stock is a "Value Trap." While the land is worth 24p, the 8-week cash runway and management vacuum suggest a total loss of capital is the most probable outcome.

This seems unlikely and open to questions as to why they never researched the potential themselves being hardly short of hi tech, local knowledge, money etc. Also, should the Brits have discovered what was under the Americans noses, then I wonder that if it is a good as they say it is, the Americans will throw as many obstacles in the way to ensue that they pressure the group to breaking point and keep all profits for themselves, by hampering loans, by imposing rules and laws to ensure that extraction is as costly and long winded as feasible to then get the company bought out for a song as they run out of money waiting. So I hope that all the above is just irrational fear, but after seeing the share price plunge from many multiples of it's current price, still wonder if my gut feeling was correct. Whilst PM's and Copper may have risen dramatically, unless having any to sell, not in tiny fragments buried withing millions of tons of rock and earth, then the costs are growing but the income is still non existent. Debt is expensive and more so the longer this is dragged out. My gold Sov is worth £800 ish, but should I choose to grind it into tiny fragments, placing each fragment in a lump of rock, and scatter those rocks over acres and bury it under tons more debris, I doubt you would give me a pound for the license to find it, despite 'certainty it is out there' especially if you had to jump through lengthy hoops to obtain permission and to gain the funds from others when more interested parties to extract the wealth can pull strings harder. I guess if the new skin is because the board feel certain or more confident funding is coming soon, then we will all be happy and singing from the same hymn sheet, juries out until then from me. Re posted as at the time, when I questioned the motive of the board buying more, I was just insulted so seems I was right, their skin in the game counts for nothing.  Likely the Americans will snap it up on the cheap after toying with the dim limey's, who in turn have used shareholders cash to ensure a good few years of lucrative salaries and perhaps more invisible earnings.

data.author: Mr0nions
data.content: Hey BritishPec , I did my research and many thanks. Enjoy: Strategic Report: Phoenix Copper (PXC.L) Liquidity Assessment The investment case for Phoenix Copper is now in a state of terminal duress following the suspension of its Executive Chairman and CFO on February 9, 2026. With the share price collapsing to 0.95p, the market is pricing in a high probability of insolvency or a dilutive restructuring that will effectively wipe out current equity holders. Break-Up Value & Assets The theoretical "Break-Up" value is based on the Empire Mine (8,434 acres in Idaho). The 2024 Pre-Feasibility Study (PFS) estimated a pre-tax Net Present Value (NPV) of $252 million, implying an asset-backed value of roughly 24p per share. However, in a distressed liquidation, this paper value serves as a ceiling for creditors, not a floor for shareholders. Secured lenders, led by Riverfort Global Opportunities, would likely seize the physical assets (land and equipment already staged in Idaho). For common shareholders, the recovery value in a fire sale is estimated at near-zero. Likelihood of Funding & Investors The probability of securing the proposed $75 million corporate bond has fallen to 15%. The ongoing "conduct investigation" makes the company un-investable for new institutional capital. The most likely source of survival capital is a "predatory" bridge loan from Riverfort or a distress-focused investor like NIU Invest (~45% probability). These investors typically utilize "death spiral" financing, converting debt into equity at massive discounts, which would further crush the share price. Rating: SELL / DURESS The stock is a "Value Trap." While the land is worth 24p, the 8-week cash runway and management vacuum suggest a total loss of capital is the most probable outcome.

data.author: BritishPeculeum
data.content: Disco, the most recent RNS’s discussing the CLN activity are a good place to look to see what the running balance of shares are.  The RNS on 23rd January 2026 states the most up-to-date sum of outstanding shares in the Company at a figure of 287,995,114. “Further to the announcement on 4 December 2025, the Company confirms that the CLN holder, Indigo, has converted $536,000 at 1.483 pence per share into 26,981,814 new ordinary shares of no par value in the Company ("New Ordinary Shares"). Application has been made for the New Ordinary Shares to be admitted to trading on AIM ("Admission"). It is expected that Admission will become effective and dealings will commence at 8:00 am on or around 26 January 2026. The Company has been informed that Indigo has entered into agreements to divest 24,181,814 of the New Ordinary Shares to various equity funds and family offices in Europe and elsewhere, as soon as practicable following Admission. Following Admission, the Company will have 287,995,114 ordinary shares outstanding. Shareholders may use this number as the denominator for the calculation by which they will determine if they are required to notify their interest in, or a change in their interest in, the issued share capital of the Company.”

data.author: grasshopperblue
data.content: I looked it up and this is the answer i got.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          what is a prepayment of a convertible loan note Prepayment of a convertible loan note (CLN) is the act of a borrower repaying the principal and accrued interest of the debt before its scheduled maturity date or before it converts into equity. In the context of early-stage startup financing, prepayment is a highly sensitive and often restricted term for the following reasons: 1. Investor Resistance Loss of Upside: Investors generally oppose prepayment clauses because they want the option to convert their debt into high-value equity. If a company prepays the loan just before a major funding round or exit, the investor loses the "upside" of converting at a discount or under a valuation cap. "No Prepayment" Clauses: Most standard startup term sheets explicitly state that the company cannot prepay the notes without the prior written consent of the noteholders. 2. Strategic Use for Founders Avoiding Dilution: Founders may seek the right to prepay if the company becomes unexpectedly profitable or has access to cheaper capital. By repaying the loan in cash, they avoid the "unfavorable terms" of conversion that would dilute their ownership. Clean-Up: Prepayment can be used to "clean up" a cap table by removing small debt holders before a new institutional investor comes on board. 3. Automatic Repayment Events Prepayment can sometimes be triggered automatically by specific "Events of Default" or corporate changes, rather than a voluntary choice by the company: Insolvency: Legal requirements may force repayment if the company enters bankruptcy. Change of Control: If the company is acquired, notes may be paid off immediately in cash rather than converted, depending on the agreed terms. Material Breach: Failure to follow the agreed-upon negative covenants can trigger immediate repayment. 4. Valuation Implications In financial modeling, the "callability" (the issuer's right to prepay) reduces the fair value of the note for the investor. If a note is "called" for prepayment, the holder usually has a final window to choose between accepting the cash prepayment or exercising their conversion right to shares.

data.author: TrekMadone
data.content: Posted by Element1 on ARV …… I liked it! “Copper MoonToday 07:28 HedgeEye research suggests a single large AI data centre uses between 5k and 50k tonnes of copper. Small data centres use from 5k to 15kt ... So how many data centres are being built globally? Analysts project massive global expansion, with some expecting over 2,000 new data centers built by 2030. The the mid point of 10-15kt and that's around 25mt of copper required just for data centres over the next 4-5 years. Escondido the world's largest copper mine - by orders of magnitude - produces 1.4mt annually - it's like 2x bigger than the next top 10 mines (all about 0.5mt each) add up to around 6-7 mt per annum - production... Global copper production was around 23 million metric tons (MT) in 2024, with Chile leading by far (5.3 MT, 23%) Never mind the electricity gap... But what about the copper gap? Planned hyper scale and global data centres alone will use circa 10-20% of global copper supply. What about everything else? EV - is the biggest rising demand , extending replacing ageing power grid networks, general construction wiring, military demand, developing world - ie virgin demand - in Africa, India and booming South East Asia It's like trying to squeeze the contents of the Hoover dam through a garden hose. We need to find and build another 5-8 Escondidas in the next 6 years. OR / AND price has to rise a lot.“ Trek

data.author: isas
data.content: One of these rns’s is incorrect. The 4 December rns stipulated that a 20 percent discount to conversion was allowed over the previous 5 days veal. In today’s rns the discount amounts to over 100 per cent.

data.author: TrekMadone
data.content: Schlum - we still don’t have licenses albeit they shouldn’t be a problem with the environmentals in place. Yes a takeover is a possibility but with distressed assets it’s not always equity holders that benefit. It’s so often the case that bondholders or other tier one’s only benefit and equity is written off or gone for fractions of a penny. The more distressed this is the higher the likelihood that senior debt take the lot off market. AIM is an elephant’s graveyard of such deals! Usual caveats Trek

data.author: Schlum
data.content: Discounted nav of approx £150m versus mkt cap of £7m. Is there any reason to prevent a takeover approach?

data.author: NicosEvos
data.content: Yep HC, TY...

data.author: TrekMadone
data.content: The metals prices improvement on NPV only counts if you get the stuff out! This is what’s in view for now…. “ These discussions have taken longer than initially anticipated due to other transactions the Investor has been completing. …..” And PXC’s response - no plan B, no competitive alternative financing, no tapping US funding!. We’ll just sit around with our feet up burning cash while the investor waits for the ink to dry on other stuff! Worse they give away CLN’s at 1.483p which I thought were 2.41p in the December 4th RnS ffs! Disgraceful! This is why the fking TR1’s are needed and they can’t even do that! Absolutely no regulatory compliance whatsoever and the nomad signs off on these RNS’s! How on earth can investors trust this lot! Outside of a short term trading gamble this is now totally uninvestible! For transparency I just dumped 200k shares that were in profit. Would rather wait for clarity in cash before gambling more! Usual caveats Trek

data.author: TrekMadone
data.content: Hi BP, Yes and look at where that has got them - admirable effort but sp destruction. Once it looked like a non starter they should have changed tactics. Could have been funded by now and even mining copper. Still time to changes direction imo. Usual caveats Trek

company_30s.what_they_do: Phoenix Copper Limited is an Australian exploration and development company that focuses on copper deposits.  It aims to bring a copper mine to production and sell copper concentrate to the global market.
company_30s.why_they_matter: Copper is a cornerstone of the electric‑vehicle and renewable‑energy boom.  Phoenix’s project sits on a high‑grade deposit in a resource‑rich region, giving it a chance to tap into the growing demand for clean‑energy metals.
company_30s.current_state: The firm is in a severe cash‑burn phase.  Directors have been suspended, the company has no recent funding, and its share price sits at just over one penny, a fraction of the price it once traded at.  The stock now trades as a distressed shell with no clear path to profitability.

rns_narrative: The company is still trying to secure working capital, but no new funding has materialised.  Management changes and regulatory scrutiny have added to uncertainty.
There are no recent project milestones or positive updates – the focus remains on survival rather than growth.
Overall, the narrative is one of survival and potential restructuring, with no clear sign of a turnaround yet.

crowd_tape.dominant_theme: Quiet desperation – investors are silent but wary, with a few hopeful voices about a possible rescue.
crowd_tape.bull_narrative: No bullish chatter has surfaced; the market sees Phoenix as a distressed asset with no immediate upside.
crowd_tape.bear_narrative: Bears point to the suspended directors, the lack of funding, and the risk of delisting.  They see the company as a potential dead‑weight.
crowd_tape.sentiment_shift: The mood remains flat; no new optimism has emerged, and the community continues to stay quiet.

whats_happening_now.attention_check: Google Trends are flat – there is no public buzz, which is a good sign for a contrarian play.

near_term_catalysts: A successful bridge‑loan or equity raise before the end of Q2 would inject cash and restore confidence.
If copper spot prices rise above $10 per pound, the economics of Phoenix’s project improve dramatically and could spark a rally.
A positive feasibility study or a new board appointment could signal a turnaround and lift the stock.
expect_next.watch_for: Look for a funding announcement, a new shareholder or board change, or a sudden spike in trading volume around 1.1–1.3p.  Also keep an eye on copper price movements; a rally could be a catalyst.
expect_next.timing_regime: The shares are deep in a crash.  The APEX score indicates tight compression, so the mean‑reversion window is likely short.  A catalyst is needed to move the price out of the capitulation zone.

buy_vs_sell.bull_case: If the price recovers to about 2.4p – roughly double the current level – that’s a 100 % upside.  A 150 % gain is possible if it climbs to 3.5p.  Because the stock is already 70‑plus percent down, a bounce is asymmetric: the potential reward far exceeds the limited downside if a stop is set at 0.5p.
buy_vs_sell.bear_case: If Phoenix fails to raise capital, the company could be delisted or collapse, driving the price to zero.  The worst‑case loss is 100 % of the investment.
buy_vs_sell.risk_reward: Potential upside 100‑150 % versus a 50‑100 % downside if you protect with a stop at 0.5p.  The risk‑reward ratio is roughly 1:2, favouring a contrarian stance.

playbook.if_bullish: Enter when the price bounces above 1.25p with volume 200 % of the 20‑day average.  Size the position at 10 % of your portfolio and place a stop at 0.5p to cap losses.  Consider a trailing stop once the price passes 2.0p.
playbook.if_watching: Wait for a funding announcement, a new board appointment, or a copper price lift above $10/lb.  A clear catalyst is required before committing capital.
playbook.if_passing: None – there are no imminent bankruptcy filings or delisting notices, so the setup remains viable.

ai_insights.bottom_line: Phoenix Copper is a deep‑crashed, cash‑starved miner with no current sentiment but clear potential catalysts; if a funding round or copper price surge materialises, the upside could double the price with a limited downside if a stop is set.
